channel.title: Comments on: Star Schema The Complete Reference â€“ Review
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Steven Neumersky
item.dc:creator: Steven Neumersky
item.description:
I started by BI career out in Oracle, and you are totally correct regarding aggregate navigation in Oracle's RDBMS engine. Furthermore, Oracle also had far better "BI-Friendly" indexing (bitmap indexes) at the turn of the century, and Oracle was FAR MORE ANSI-99 compliant with OLAP functions in the RDBMS than SQL Server.
Today, however, SSAS is a more outstanding OLAP engine--virtually top-of-the-class, along with being more cost effective for many enterprises.
With more and more technology being pushed down to SQL Server's RDBMS engine (bitmaps, compression, star-join optimization, etc), ROLAP/Direct Query Mode/Indexed Views may start to become more widely used than they were years ago.
item.content:encoded:
I started by BI career out in Oracle, and you are totally correct regarding aggregate navigation in Oracle’s RDBMS engine. Furthermore, Oracle also had far better “BI-Friendly” indexing (bitmap indexes) at the turn of the century, and Oracle was FAR MORE ANSI-99 compliant with OLAP functions in the RDBMS than SQL Server.

Today, however, SSAS is a more outstanding OLAP engine–virtually top-of-the-class, along with being more cost effective for many enterprises.

With more and more technology being pushed down to SQL Server’s RDBMS engine (bitmaps, compression, star-join optimization, etc), ROLAP/Direct Query Mode/Indexed Views may start to become more widely used than they were years ago.

item.title: By: Koen Verbeeck
item.dc:creator: Koen Verbeeck
item.description:
I have heard Oracle is pretty good at aggregates as they apparently behave like indexes: updated automatically, almost no maintenance and invisible to end users.
I might give the "Mastering Data Warehouse Aggregates" book a try sometime.
item.content:encoded:
I have heard Oracle is pretty good at aggregates as they apparently behave like indexes: updated automatically, almost no maintenance and invisible to end users.

I might give the “Mastering Data Warehouse Aggregates” book a try sometime.

item.title: By: Steven Neumersky
item.dc:creator: Steven Neumersky
item.description: Mastering Data Warehouse Aggregates by Adamson is not bad either--albeit a little "dated" in doing manual aggregate navigation. Personally, I like to get an "old school" base because many concepts today are just riffs on the foundations set by our BI "Forefathers".
item.content:encoded: Mastering Data Warehouse Aggregates by Adamson is not bad either–albeit a little “dated” in doing manual aggregate navigation. Personally, I like to get an “old school” base because many concepts today are just riffs on the foundations set by our BI “Forefathers”.
